body:
Well that's weird.
I did move the toString() impls a bit in either build 40 or 41 (they were inline but now the impl part - the bit you found at line 7165 - is only compiled in to the source file that #defines `CATCH_CONFIG_MAIN` or `CATCH_CONFIG_RUNNER`). The prototype is at line 844.

But I just checked (again) in my OC test project and it all seems to work fine. I even tried your example, to see if there was anything specific about it. A couple of things I noted there:
1. You wrote `CATCH` for the assertion. I presume you meant `CHECK`?
2. Because of the interplay between ARC and templates I can't compare the NSString directly against nil - I have to cast the nil to an NSString\* - so my test was actually like this:

```
NSString *string = @"not null";
CHECK((NSString*)nil != string);
```

But that all builds fine.

I'll take another look tomorrow. If you're able to boil it down to the minimal complete example that fails that might help too. Thanks!

issue.title: Build 42: clang unknown pragma warning/error

repository.name: Catch2
repository.description: A modern, C++-native, test framework for unit-tests, TDD and BDD - using C++14, C++17 and later (C++11 support is in v2.x branch, and C++03 on the Catch1.x branch)

issue.body:
Build 42 introduced 2 new clang ignore pragmas. On clang 3.4 (Xcode 5.1.1) they produce  an ignored pragma warning; or worse an error if -Werror is enabled.

catch.hpp:24:34: error: unknown warning group '-WGeneralized initializer lists are incompatible with C++98', ignored [-Werror,-Wunknown-pragmas]

catch.hpp:25:34: error: unknown warning group '-WRvalue references are incompatible with C++98', ignored [-Werror,-Wunknown-pragmas]

clang --version
Apple LLVM version 5.1 (clang-503.0.40) (based on LLVM 3.4svn)

body:
Interesting - I wonder if it is an ARC thing? I don't remember the details - would have to play with it again - but presumably I needed that const in there.
I'd been toying with the idea of taking the MRC support out at this point - I wasn't sure if anyone was using it!
I'm not going to get a chance to look at this in more depth again until at least the end of this week. I hope you're workaround is ok to get you going for now?

Maybe for iOS MRC has gone to almost to nil use, but I think there is still a lot of OSX MRC legacy code out there. For us there sure is. You could make the const conditional as part of the CATCH_ARC_STRONG macro or another macro CATCH_ARC_CONST_REF

Yeah - don't worry - I'm not going to remove MRC support. I'll have a look again (probably next week) at that reference. It certainly used to work without ARC - but not tried it for quite a while. Will try again with 5.1.1

Hi @bdb,

Sorry for the delay getting back - was pretty tied up last week.
I've now tried your complete example, exactly as you wrote (thanks for providing that). I also disabled ARC.
It still compiles - and runs - just fine for me!

We're both using Xcode 5.1.1. I presume you're using LLVM 5.1?
I tried it form both Mac and iOS targets.
I can't think what else might be different (unless you're using GCC?).

Yes, Xcode 5.1.1 and LLVM/Clang. I just tried this again with a clean project and Catch 43 still gets a linker error. Catch 33 works fine.

I wonder if its something to do with compiler flags. We are using -O0 (so auto-inline is off) -std=c++11 -stdlib=libc++   -fvisibility=hidden

I wonder if it has something to do with auto-inline. Those functions are small enough they should be inlined, but since its not explicit in the header -O0 won't do it automatically.

Here's a larger excerpt of the compile flags:

export LANG=en_US.US-ASCII
    /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Toolchains/XcodeDefault.xctoolchain/usr/bin/clang -x objective-c++ -arch x86_64 -O0 -Wno-missing-field-initializers -Wno-missing-prototypes -Wno-return-type -Wno-implicit-atomic-properties -Wno-receiver-is-weak -Wno-arc-repeated-use-of-weak -Wno-non-virtual-dtor -Wno-overloaded-virtual -Wno-exit-time-destructors -Wno-missing-braces -Wparentheses -Wswitch -Wno-unused-function -Wno-unused-label -Wno-unused-parameter -Wno-unused-variable -Wunused-value -Wno-empty-body -Wno-uninitialized -Wno-unknown-pragmas -Wno-shadow -Wno-four-char-constants -Wno-conversion -Wno-constant-conversion -Wno-int-conversion -Wno-bool-conversion -Wno-enum-conversion -Wno-shorten-64-to-32 -Wno-newline-eof -Wno-selector -Wno-strict-selector-match -Wno-undeclared-selector -Wno-deprecated-implementations -Wno-c++11-extensions -isysroot /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/SDKs/MacOSX10.9.sdk -fasm-blocks -fstrict-aliasing -Wprotocol -Wdeprecated-declarations -Winvalid-offsetof -mmacosx-version-min=10.7 -g -fvisibility=hidden

I am unable to check this one on my own, can someone else try if it is still relevant?

I'd expect its not, but apparently someone referenced this only couple of months ago.
I've hit this again with 1.5.7 and had to work around it. Not sure why it cropped up again. Upgrading to 1.6.0 is on my todo list.

Glad to see you're still watching, @bdb - but sorry to hear you're still having problems (or having them again).
I very much doubt anything relevant has changed between 1.5.7 and 1.6.0 - although it's always worth getting confirmation.
I'll try this again myself. I know I wasn't able to reproduce it before, but it looks like since I was last looking at this you posted your compiler flags, so I'll see if using those makes the difference.
1.6 has the same issue and the same patch fixes it.
Looks like to reproduce all you need is for main() to be in a C++ file, not Objective-C++. Then you'll get the error. ARC/MRC doesn't seem to be relevant.

issue.title: Fix Catch::toString() linker error when main() is compiled as C++

repository.name: Catch2
repository.description: A modern, C++-native, test framework for unit-tests, TDD and BDD - using C++14, C++17 and later (C++11 support is in v2.x branch, and C++03 on the Catch1.x branch)

body:
I wrote a minimum reproducible case:

Two main files `main.cpp` and `main.mm`, each with exact contents:

    #define CATCH_CONFIG_MAIN
    #include "catch.hpp"

and a test file `test.mm`:

    #include "catch.hpp"
    TEST_CASE("test") {
        NSString *msg = @"test";
        CHECK(msg != (NSString*)nil);
    }

Then I used this `Makefile`:

    LDFLAGS := -stdlib=libc++ -framework Foundation
    
    all: mm_noarc mm_arc cpp_noarc cpp_arc
    
    mm_noarc:
    	clang++ main.mm test.mm -o $@ $(LDFLAGS)
    
    mm_arc:
    	clang++ -fobjc-arc main.mm test.mm -o $@ $(LDFLAGS)
    
    cpp_noarc:
    	clang++ main.cpp test.mm -o $@ $(LDFLAGS)
    
    cpp_arc:
    	clang++ -fobjc-arc main.cpp test.mm -o $@ $(LDFLAGS)
    
    clean:
    	rm -rf mm_noarc mm_arc cpp_noarc cpp_arc

The cpp_* targets will fail with current Catch, and pass with the fix from @bdb.

I tested with ARC/MRC just to see if those were related, but they are not. Still not clear why it fails. I've never seen `const` used with any of Cocoa's APIs, so it's probably best to avoid it altogether.
